title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Multi-stage games: overview






Object of analysis


How commitment in earlier stages changes equilibrium behaviour in later stages.




So far:

Mostly simultaneous-move games
Briefly: two-stage game (Shy (1995) model in Lecture 4)

Today:

Stackelberg quantity leadership
Strategic delegation (Vickers, 1985)

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Solution concept: subgame perfect equilibrium

A strategy profile is a subgame perfect Nash equilibrium (SPNE) if it induces a Nash equilibrium in every subgame
Operationally (finite horizon):

Solve from the last stage backward (backward induction)








Commitment logic


A first-stage action changes the feasible set faced by later movers (via best responses), not the payoff function.

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Stackelberg model: structure

Two stages, two firms:

Leader chooses \(q_1\)
Follower observes \(q_1\) and chooses \(q_2\)

Demand and costs:

Inverse demand: \(p(Q)=A-Q\) with \(Q=q_1+q_2\)
Marginal cost: \(c\) (parameter)

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Stackelberg model: follower best response

Follower profit given \(q_1\):

\[
\pi_2(q_2;q_1) = (A-q_1-q_2-c)q_2
\]

Best response:

\[
BR_2(q_1)=\frac{A-c-q_1}{2}
\]






Strategic substitutes (quantities)


Quantities are strategic substitutes: when the rival increases output, my best-response output decreases (downward-sloping best response).

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Stackelberg v Cournot: equilibrium outcomes

Identical marginal costs (\(c\)) imply:









Outcome
Stackelberg
Cournot




Firm 1 output
\(q_1^S=\frac{A-c}{2}\)
\(q_1^C=\frac{A-c}{3}\)


Firm 2 output
\(q_2^S=\frac{A-c}{4}\)
\(q_2^C=\frac{A-c}{3}\)


Aggregate output
\(Q^S=\frac{3(A-c)}{4}\)
\(Q^C=\frac{2(A-c)}{3}\)


Price
\(p^S=\frac{A+3c}{4}\)
\(p^C=\frac{A+2c}{3}\)


Firm 1 profit
\(\pi_1^S=\frac{(A-c)^2}{8}\)
\(\pi_1^C=\frac{(A-c)^2}{9}\)


Firm 2 profit
\(\pi_2^S=\frac{(A-c)^2}{16}\)
\(\pi_2^C=\frac{(A-c)^2}{9}\)

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Stackelberg model: remarks

Comparative statics questions:

What changes when marginal costs are asymmetric?
What changes if the timing is endogenous (announcement/commitment issues)?

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Stackelberg: numerical example (\(A=10\), \(c=1\))

Parameters: \(A=10\) (demand intercept), \(c=1\) (marginal cost)
Stackelberg outcomes:

\(q_1^S=\frac{A-c}{2}=4.5\); \(q_2^S=\frac{A-c}{4}=2.25\)
\(Q^S=6.75\); \(p^S=A-Q^S=3.25\)
\(\pi_1^S=(p^S-c)q_1^S=10.125\)

Cournot benchmark:

\(\pi_1^C=\frac{(A-c)^2}{9}=9\)








Concrete comparison


With \(A=10\), \(c=1\): \(\pi_1^S=10.125 > \pi_1^C=9\) (first-mover advantage).

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Stackelberg: welfare comparison (to Cournot)

With linear demand \(p=A-Q\) and constant marginal cost \(c\):

Higher total output implies lower price \(\Rightarrow\) higher consumer surplus (CS)
Stackelberg yields \(Q^S>\,Q^C\) (hence \(CS^S>CS^C\))

Total surplus changes because:

CS rises with \(Q\)
profits can rise for the leader and fall for the follower relative to Cournot








Exam-useful statement


Stackelberg leadership typically increases output relative to Cournot, so it is (weakly) better for consumers.

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Delegation: economic idea

Firms may delegate output choice to managers with objectives that differ from pure profit maximisation
Delegation instrument:

an incentive parameter \(\theta_i\) written into the manager’s contract

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Delegation (Vickers): model

Cournot oligopoly with \(n\) firms: \(i=1,\dots,n\)
Manager of firm \(i\) maximises:

\[
M_i=\pi_i+\theta_i q_i
\]
where \(\pi_i=p(Q)q_i-cq_i\) and \(Q=\sum_i q_i\)






Equivalent formulation


\(M_i = p(Q)q_i - (c-\theta_i)q_i\) so \(\theta_i\) shifts the manager’s objective like a reduction in marginal cost.









Commitment assumption


For delegation to affect rivals’ behaviour, contracts must be:

observable (rivals see \(\theta_i\))
binding (owners cannot override managers after \(\theta_i\) is set)

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Delegation: triopoly exercise (setup)

Cournot triopoly: \(i=1,2,3\)
Demand: \(p(Q)=A-Q\)
Identical marginal costs: \(c\)
Managers: \(\theta_i \ge 0\)
Task:

Solve the \(\theta\)-setting game given the induced Cournot equilibrium in \((q_1,q_2,q_3)\)

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Delegation: triopoly solution steps

Step 1 (product-market subgame): given \((\theta_1,\theta_2,\theta_3)\), managers play Cournot and determine \(q_i^*(\theta)\)
Step 2 (contract stage): each owner chooses \(\theta_i\) to maximise own profit \(\pi_i(\theta_i;\theta_{-i})\)
Step 3 (equilibrium incentives): solve the system of best responses in \(\theta\)

in symmetry: \(\theta_1=\theta_2=\theta_3=\hat{\theta}\)








Exam template


Two-stage delegation problems are solved exactly like Stackelberg: solve the quantity subgame first, then solve the incentive-setting stage.

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Delegation: triopoly equilibrium (given)
Cournot–Nash equilibrium outcomes (given incentives \(\theta_i\)):
\[
q_i^*=\frac{1}{4}\left(A-c+3\theta_i-\sum_{j\ne i}\theta_j\right)
\]
\[
p^*=\frac{1}{4}\left(A+3c-\sum_i \theta_i\right)
\]

Interpretation:

Increasing \(\theta_i\) shifts \(q_i^*\) up; rivals’ incentives are strategic substitutes in outputs through \(Q\)

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Delegation: solving for equilibrium incentives
Owner’s problem (taking rivals’ incentives as given):

Owner maximises profit (not managerial utility):

\[
\max_{\theta_i \ge 0}\ \pi_i^*(\theta_i;\theta_{-i})=\big(p^*(\theta)-c\big)\,q_i^*(\theta)
\]
First-order condition:
\[
\frac{\partial \pi_i^*(\theta_i;\theta_{-i})}{\partial \theta_i}=0
\]

Solving the three FOCs gives a best-response system in \((\theta_1,\theta_2,\theta_3)\)
In symmetry, \(\theta_i=\hat{\theta}\) for all \(i\), implying \(\hat{\theta}=\frac{1}{5}(A-c)\)

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Delegation: best response in incentives (triopoly)
Define the rivals’ average incentive:
\[
\bar{\theta}_{-i}=\frac{1}{n-1}\sum_{j\ne i}\theta_j \quad (n=3)
\]
A reduced-form best response for the owner’s incentive choice can be written as:
\[
\theta_i = BR(\theta_{-i})=\frac{1}{3}(A-c)-\frac{2}{3}\bar{\theta}_{-i}
\]

Interpretation:

Higher rival incentives make rivals more aggressive, reducing the marginal gain from raising \(\theta_i\)

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Delegation: symmetric equilibrium (fixed point)
In symmetry, \(\theta_i=\bar{\theta}_{-i}=\hat{\theta}\) for all \(i\).
\[
\hat{\theta}=\frac{1}{3}(A-c)-\frac{2}{3}\hat{\theta}
\quad \Rightarrow \quad
\hat{\theta}=\frac{1}{5}(A-c)
\]






What this is doing


This is the standard “best-response fixed point” method: compute \(BR(\cdot)\), then impose symmetry.

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Delegation: strategic logic






Prisoners’ dilemma



Unilateral incentive: if rivals set \(\theta=0\), I benefit from choosing \(\theta_i>0\)

Positive \(\theta_i\) commits my manager to higher output
Rivals reduce output (quantities are strategic substitutes)

Equilibrium outcome: all firms choose \(\hat{\theta}>0\)

The strategic advantage disappears when everyone delegates
Profits fall: \(\hat{\pi}<\pi^C\) (overproduction lowers price for all)


Each owner chooses \(\theta_i\) optimally given rivals’ choices, but the collective outcome is worse than \(\theta=0\).

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Delegation: comparison table (triopoly)

\(\hat{q}=\frac{3(A-c)}{10}\)

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Delegation: numerical example (\(A=10\), \(c=1\))

Parameters: \(A=10\), \(c=1\)
Delegation equilibrium:

\(\hat{\theta}=\frac{A-c}{5}=1.8\)
Per-firm profit: \(\hat{\pi}=\frac{3(A-c)^2}{100}=2.43\)

Cournot triopoly benchmark (\(\theta_i=0\)):

Per-firm profit: \(\pi^C=\frac{(A-c)^2}{16}=5.0625\)








Concrete comparison


With \(A=10\), \(c=1\): \(\hat{\pi}=2.43 < \pi^C=5.0625\) (delegation intensifies competition and lowers profits).

title: Lecture 5 – Multi-stage Games
text:
Delegation: welfare comparison (to Cournot triopoly)

Delegation increases effective aggressiveness in output:

equilibrium price is lower than in standard Cournot triopoly
therefore consumer surplus is higher under delegation than under \(\theta_i=0\)

Total surplus effect:

CS rises due to lower price
profits fall due to overproduction relative to joint-profit motives








Exam-useful statement


Delegation can be privately attractive ex ante (as a commitment device) but can reduce profits in equilibrium while benefiting consumers.

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Innovation: types and stages
Why study innovation?

Innovation is a stochastic process
Probability of success depends on resources allocated

Types:

Process innovation: shifts cost function (typically lowers marginal cost)
Product innovation: shifts demand function

Stages:

Research → Development → Adoption

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Innovation and competition: two-way relation
Two-way relationship:

How market structure affects incentives to innovate
How innovation affects market structure

Key question:

Compare maximum willingness to pay (WTP) for innovation across market structures:

Monopoly (before and after innovation)
Perfect competition (before; monopoly rights after)
Social planner


Interpretation:

Firm WTP: maximum lump-sum payment that leaves profit unchanged, i.e. \(\text{WTP} = \Delta \pi\)
Planner WTP: maximum lump-sum payment that leaves welfare unchanged, i.e. \(\text{WTP} = \Delta W\)

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
section: Example: linear demand and process innovation
text:
Example: linear demand and process innovation
Market demand (inverse):
\[
P(Q) = A - Q
\]
Process innovation:

Marginal cost falls from \(c_0\) to \(c_1\) where \(c_1 < c_0 < A\)

Variables:

Parameters: \(A, c_0, c_1\)
Choice variables: \(Q\) (monopoly / planner), and later \(p\) in price competition
Outcomes: \(Q^m(c)\), \(P^m(c)\), \(\pi^m(c)\)

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
section: Monopoly (before and after innovation): problem and FOC
text:
Monopoly (before and after innovation): problem and FOC
Monopoly problem:
\[
\max_Q \ (A - Q - c)Q
\]
First-order condition:
\[
A - 2Q - c = 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad Q^m(c) = \frac{A-c}{2}
\]
Interpretation:

\(Q\) is the choice variable; \(A\) and \(c\) are parameters
Lower \(c\) increases the monopoly’s optimal output

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
section: Monopoly (before and after innovation): outcomes and WTP
text:
Monopoly (before and after innovation): outcomes and WTP
Equilibrium outcomes:

Price: \(P^m(c) = \frac{A+c}{2}\)
Profit: \(\pi^m(c) = \frac{(A-c)^2}{4}\)

Max WTP for innovation:
\[
\Delta \pi^m = \pi^m(c_1) - \pi^m(c_0) = \frac{(A-c_1)^2 - (A-c_0)^2}{4}
\]
Interpretation:

\(\Delta \pi^m\) is the monopoly’s value of exclusive access to the lower cost \(c_1\)

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Perfect competition (before; monopoly rights after)
Before innovation (all firms at MC \(c_0\)):

Competitive price: \(P^{pc}_0 = c_0\)
Firm profit: \(\pi = 0\)

After innovation (innovator has exclusive use):

If innovation is drastic: innovator behaves as monopolist at cost \(c_1\)
If non-drastic: innovator constrained by competitive fringe at \(c_0\)

Key insight:

Competitive firm can be willing to pay more than monopolist
Creates profit rather than replacing existing profit

Interpretation:

Under perfect competition pre-innovation, rents are (approximately) zero, so innovation primarily creates rents for the innovator
Under monopoly pre-innovation, some rents already exist, so innovation partly replaces them

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
section: Size of process innovation: drastic v non-drastic
text:
Size of process innovation: drastic v non-drastic
Definitions:

Drastic (major) innovation: innovator behaves as unconstrained monopolist
Non-drastic (minor) innovation: innovator has cost advantage but remains constrained by rivals

Criterion:
Innovation is drastic if monopoly price at cost \(c_1\) falls below rivals’ cost \(c_0\):
\[
P^m(c_1) < c_0 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \frac{A+c_1}{2} < c_0 \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad A + c_1 < 2c_0
\]
Interpretation:

If \(P^m(c_1) \ge c_0\), the fringe constrains price (limit pricing), so monopoly pricing at cost \(c_1\) is not feasible
“Drastic” is a statement about whether rivals are binding constraints on the innovator’s pricing

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Replacement effect (Arrow, 1972)
Key result:

Monopolist has positive pre-innovation profits → innovation partly replaces existing profits
Competitive firm earns (near) zero pre-innovation profits → innovation creates new profits

Implication:

Competitive firm may be willing to pay more than monopolist for same innovation
Pre-existing market power can reduce innovation incentives (ceteris paribus)

Caveat:

With entry threat, incumbents may value innovation for pre-emption (later section)

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Social planner: efficient output
Efficient output for demand \(P(Q)=A-Q\) and marginal cost \(c\):
\[
P(Q) = c \quad \Rightarrow \quad Q^{sp}(c) = A - c
\]
Interpretation:

Efficiency sets price equal to marginal cost (allocative efficiency)
Lower \(c\) increases the efficient quantity one-for-one

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Social planner: welfare and WTP
Total surplus (welfare):
\[
W(c) = \int_0^{A-c} (A - Q - c) \, dQ = \frac{(A-c)^2}{2}
\]
Max WTP for innovation (social planner):
\[
\Delta W = W(c_1) - W(c_0) = \frac{(A-c_1)^2 - (A-c_0)^2}{2}
\]
Interpretation:

The planner values innovation more than a monopolist because it internalises the output expansion effect

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Incentives to innovate in oligopoly
Earlier ranking (under specific assumptions):

Max WTP: Social planner > Competitive firm > Monopoly

But in oligopoly:

Incentives need not be monotone in competition intensity
Key drivers:

Number of firms (\(n\))
Product differentiation
Type of competition (price vs quantity)


Interpretation:

Innovation changes relative costs or demands; its payoff depends on how strongly rivals’ actions respond (strategic interaction)

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
section: Impact of number of firms (Cournot intuition)
text:
Impact of number of firms (Cournot intuition)
Linear Cournot with \(n\) firms:

Innovation incentives can follow inverse-U as \(n\) increases

Two opposing effects as \(n \uparrow\):

Competition effect: profits for all firms fall (discourages innovation)
Competitive advantage effect: cost advantage becomes more valuable when there are more inefficient rivals (encourages innovation)

Interpretation:

“More rivals” reduces the baseline profit level, but increases the value of being the low-cost firm relative to the rest

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Monopoly threatened by entry: setup
Incumbent monopoly faces potential entrant:

Both can acquire innovation reducing MC from \(c_0\) to \(c_1 < c_0\)
Entrant can enter profitably only if it gets innovation

Payoffs:

If incumbent gets innovation: entrant stays out

Incumbent: \(\pi^m(c_1)\); Entrant: \(0\)

If entrant gets innovation: entrant enters

Incumbent: \(\pi^d(c_0, c_1)\); Entrant: \(\pi^d(c_1, c_0)\)


Interpretation:

Innovation has a strategic value by changing market structure (monopoly vs duopoly)

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Efficiency effect (Gilbert and Newbery, 1982): values
Per-period value of innovation:
\[
V_I = \pi^m(c_1) - \pi^d(c_0, c_1)
\]
\[
V_E = \pi^d(c_1, c_0)
\]
Interpretation:

Incumbent value \(V_I\) measures the loss avoided by preventing entry (monopoly preserved)
Entrant value \(V_E\) is the profit created by entering with the cost advantage

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Efficiency effect (Gilbert and Newbery, 1982): condition
Incumbent has higher incentives if:
\[
V_I > V_E \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad \pi^m(c_1) > \pi^d(c_1, c_0) + \pi^d(c_0, c_1)
\]
Holds typically when products are close substitutes
Interpretation:

The incumbent internalises the effect of innovation on market structure (monopoly vs duopoly)

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Dasgupta and Stiglitz (1980): setup
Question: Does more firms imply more innovation?
Primitives:

\(U(Q)\) = gross social benefit
\(c = c(x)\) = constant marginal cost depending on R&D expenditure \(x\)
Assumption: \(c'(x) < 0\) (R&D reduces cost)

Social optimum:
\[
\max_{x,Q} \ V(x,Q) = U(Q) - c(x)Q - x
\]
First-order condition in \(x\):
\[
-c'(x)Q = 1
\]
Interpretation:

Optimal R&D increases with scale \(Q\): a larger market makes cost reduction more valuable

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Dasgupta and Stiglitz (1980): firm problem
Firm \(i\)’s problem (symmetric firms):
\[
\max_{x_i, q_i} \ \pi(x_i, q_i) = [P(q_i + q_{-i}) - c(x_i)]q_i - x_i
\]
Symmetric equilibrium:

\(q_1^* = \cdots = q_N^* = Q^*/N\) and \(x_1^* = \cdots = x_N^* = x^*\)

First-order condition in \(q_i\):
\[
P(Q^*)\left(1 - \frac{\varepsilon}{N}\right) = c(x^*)
\]
where \(\varepsilon = -\frac{\partial Q}{\partial P}\frac{P}{Q}\) is demand elasticity
Interpretation:

The term \(\left(1-\frac{\varepsilon}{N}\right)\) captures market power via the perceived demand elasticity under Cournot

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
section: Dasgupta and Stiglitz (1980): free entry (zero profit)
text:
Dasgupta and Stiglitz (1980): free entry (zero profit)
Zero profit condition (free entry):
\[
\pi = 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad (P - c)\frac{Q^*}{N^*} - x^* = 0
\]
Rearrange:
\[
P - c = N^* \frac{x^*}{Q^*}
\]

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Dasgupta and Stiglitz (1980): free entry (implication)
Key implication: Concentration and research intensity are jointly determined (no simple causal link)
Interpretation:

Entry expands \(N\) until operating surplus covers R&D outlays \(x^*\)

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Dasgupta and Stiglitz (1980): equilibrium concentration
Define innovative potential:
\[
\alpha = -\frac{dc(x)}{dx}\frac{x}{c}
\]
Equilibrium concentration satisfies:
\[
\frac{1}{N^*} = \frac{1}{\varepsilon} \cdot \frac{\alpha}{1+\alpha}
\]
Interpretation:

Higher \(\alpha\) (greater innovative potential) → higher concentration
More elastic demand → lower concentration

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Dasgupta (1986): additional results (part 1)
With \(P(Q) = \sigma Q^{-\varepsilon}\) and \(c(x) = \beta x^{-\alpha}\):
Dynamic vs static efficiency trade-off:

\(x^*(N+1) < x^*(N)\) (more firms → less R&D per firm)
\(Q^*(N+1) > Q^*(N)\) (more firms → higher output)

Research intensity:

Often maximized at moderate concentration (Scherer-style inverse-U)

Interpretation:

Market structure affects both static outcomes (\(Q\)) and dynamic investment incentives (\(x\))

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Dasgupta (1986): additional results (part 2)
Greater innovative opportunities associated with higher concentration:
\[
\frac{\partial (1/N^*)}{\partial \alpha} > 0
\]
Demand growth stimulates R&D:
\[
\frac{\partial x^*}{\partial \sigma} > 0
\]
Interpretation:

Larger markets (higher \(\sigma\)) increase the return to cost reduction
Stronger innovative opportunities (higher \(\alpha\)) can support higher concentration in equilibrium

title: Lecture 3 - Innovation
text:
Summary

Innovation value depends on the objective: \(\Delta \pi\) (firm) versus \(\Delta W\) (planner)
Replacement effect: pre-innovation rents reduce the monopolist’s incremental gain from innovation
With entry threat, innovation has strategic value via market structure (monopoly vs duopoly)
In oligopoly, incentives reflect competing forces (competition effect vs advantage effect)

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Industrial Organisation: Overview
Economic models rest on key assumptions about market structure and firm behaviour.
Under perfect competition:

Markets are efficient
Price equals marginal cost

Under imperfect competition:

Markets generate welfare losses
Strategic firm behaviour matters

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Beyond Static Models
In reality, many markets feature:

Dynamic entry/exit: Number of firms changes over time
Product differentiation: Firms compete on product variety
Technological change: Innovation and R&D investment
Demand shifts: Advertising and marketing effects

\(\rightarrow\) Static models provide a foundation, but IO studies these dynamic elements.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
section: Case: Alcoa as a Natural Monopoly
text:
Case: Alcoa as a Natural Monopoly






Note


Sources of market power in early aluminium production (c. 1886–1914).




Patent advantage (1886): Smelting process patented; only a small number of firms can produce at scale initially.
Economies of scale: Alcoa expands output and develops downstream markets (intermediate and final aluminium products).
Input foreclosure (energy): In 1893, Alcoa contracts in advance for hydroelectric power from Niagara Falls.
Input foreclosure (bauxite): Alcoa secures major North American bauxite sources.
Dynamic efficiency and entry deterrence: Cost reductions make entry difficult even after patent expiration.
Institutional environment: Public policy, tariff protection, and limited antitrust enforcement before 1914.

Cournot Quantity Competition
Firm \(i\)’s maximisation problem:
\[
\max_{q_i}\; q_i\left(P(q_i + q_{-i}) - c(q_i)\right)
\]
Cournot Pricing Formula:
\[
\frac{P - c'(q_i)}{P} = \frac{\alpha_i}{\eta}
\]
Where:

\(\alpha_i = \frac{q_i}{Q}\) is firm \(i\)’s market share
\(\eta = -\frac{dQ/Q}{dP/P}\) is the price elasticity of demand
LHS is the Lerner index (mark-up rate)

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Cournot Pricing Formula: Interpretation






Key Insight


The mark-up is directly proportional to market share and inversely related to demand elasticity.

Larger market share → higher mark-up
More elastic demand → lower mark-up




This formula shows how market power arises from market concentration.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Welfare Measures in Equilibrium
Three welfare concepts:

Consumer Surplus (CS): Benefit to buyers
Producer Surplus (PS): Profit to firms
Welfare Loss (WL): Deadweight loss from inefficiency

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Equilibrium Welfare Comparison









Market Structure
Consumer Surplus
Producer Surplus
Welfare Loss




Perfect Competition
Max
0
0


Monopoly
Low
High

Cournot Oligopoly

Key Finding


Cournot oligopoly equilibrium is constrained efficient: it maximises neither consumer surplus nor aggregate surplus—the outcome reflects strategic interdependence without coordination.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Example: Three-Firm Market
Setup:

Demand: \(P = 20 - Q\)
Marginal costs: \(c_1 = 0\), \(c_2 = 5\), \(c_3 = 7\)

Perfect Competition (firm 1 at \(p = MC = 0\)):

\(\text{CS} = 200, \quad \text{PS} = 0, \quad \text{WL} = 0\)

Monopoly (firm 1 alone):

\(\text{CS} = 50, \quad \text{PS} = 100, \quad \text{WL} = 50\)

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Derivation of Cournot Triopoly
Cournot Triopoly:

\(\text{CS} = 72, \quad \text{PS} < 96, \quad \text{WL} > 32\)

\(\rightarrow\) Oligopoly equilibrium output lies strictly between monopoly and perfect competition; price and profits are correspondingly intermediate.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Cournot Welfare Maximand
Equilibrium maximises a weighted combination:
\[
\max_Q \left\{ (n-1)\big[u(Q) - P(Q)Q\big] + n\big[P(Q)Q - nc(Q/n)\big] \right\}
\]
With \(u'(Q) = P(Q)\) and \(n\) identical firms.
Interpretation:

Weight on PS is too high vs. social optimum (full competition)
Weight on PS is too low vs. monopoly outcome (full collusion)







Note


Oligopoly equilibrium reflects the tension between individual profit maximisation and the aggregate effect of firms’ choices on market price and quantity.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Welfare Weights Across Market Structures
Recall the Cournot welfare maximand:
\[
\max_Q \left\{ (n-1)\big[u(Q) - P(Q)Q\big] + n\big[P(Q)Q - nc(Q/n)\big] \right\}
\]
Interpreting the weights \((n-1)\) and \(n\) at extreme cases:
Perfect Competition: \(n \to \infty\)
\[\text{Weight on CS} = (n-1) \to \infty\] \[\text{Weight on PS} = n \to \infty \quad \text{(but each firm gets } \pi_i = \tfrac{n \cdot \pi}{n} \approx 0\text{)}\]
Result: The welfare function places infinite weight on consumer surplus relative to individual firm profits. The equilibrium maximises CS subject to firms earning zero economic profit.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Welfare Weights Across Market Structures
Monopoly: \(n = 1\)
\[\text{Weight on CS} = (n-1) = 0\] \[\text{Weight on PS} = n = 1\]
Result: The monopolist ignores consumer surplus entirely and maximises its own profit alone. The equilibrium is the unconstrained monopoly outcome.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Welfare Weights Across Market Structures
Cournot Oligopoly: \(1 < n < \infty\)
\[\text{Weight on CS} = (n-1) \in (0, \infty)\] \[\text{Weight on PS} = n \in (1, \infty)\]
Result: Oligopoly equilibrium balances consumer and producer surplus with intermediate weights. The outcome reflects the tension between:

Individual firm profit incentives (weight \(n\))
Aggregate demand response to total output (weight \(n-1\))







Interpretation


As \(n\) increases from 1 to \(\infty\), the weight on consumer surplus grows relative to producer surplus, driving equilibrium output toward the competitive level and price toward marginal cost.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
section: Cournot vs. Bertrand: Strategic Variables Matter
text:
Cournot vs. Bertrand: Strategic Variables Matter
Core question: Do firms compete on quantity or price?









Model
Strategic Variable
Best Response
Competitiveness




Cournot
Quantity
Downward-sloping
Less competitive


Bertrand
Price
Upward-sloping
More competitive



Key insight: The choice of strategic variable fundamentally affects market outcomes.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Cournot with Differentiated Products
Inverse demand functions:
\[P_1 = a - bq_1 - dq_2\] \[P_2 = a - dq_1 - bq_2\]
Parameters:

\(b > |d|\) (own effect > cross effect)
\(d \in (-b, b)\) measures product differentiation

Interpretation of \(d\):

\(d < 0\): Goods are complements
\(d = 0\): Goods are independent
\(d > 0\): Goods are substitutes

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Cournot with Substitutes: Best Response
For substitute goods (\(d > 0\)):
\[
BR_i(q_j) = \frac{a - dq_j - c_i}{2b}
\]
Key feature: Downward-sloping best response
\(\rightarrow\) Quantities are strategic substitutes

If competitor increases output, my optimal response is to decrease output
This dampening of quantities is characteristic of strategic substitutes

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Bertrand with Differentiated Products
Demand functions:
\[Q_1 = \tilde{a} - \tilde{b}p_1 + \tilde{d}p_2\] \[Q_2 = \tilde{a} + \tilde{d}p_1 - \tilde{b}p_2\]
Parameters transform the problem:

\(\tilde{a} = \frac{a}{b+d}\)
\(\tilde{b} = \frac{b}{b^2 - d^2}\)
\(\tilde{d} = \frac{d}{b^2 - d^2}\)

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Bertrand with Substitutes: Best Response
For substitute goods (\(d > 0\)):
\[
BR_i(p_j) = \frac{\tilde{a} + \tilde{d}p_j + \tilde{b}c_i}{2\tilde{b}}
\]
Key feature: Upward-sloping best response
\(\rightarrow\) Prices are strategic complements

If competitor raises price, my optimal response is to raise price
This price complementarity reflects firms’ incentive to maintain price alignment

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Cournot vs. Bertrand: Equilibrium Prices
Cournot equilibrium (\(c_i = 0\)):
\[p_i^C = \frac{ab}{2b + d}\]
Bertrand equilibrium (\(c_i = 0\)):
\[p_i^B = \frac{a(b-d)}{2b - d}\]
Price comparison:
\[p_i^C - p_i^B = \frac{ad^2}{4b^2 - d^2} > 0\]






Competition Intensity


Price competition (Bertrand) leads to lower prices and larger quantities than quantity competition (Cournot).
The strategic variable selection determines equilibrium price, output, and total welfare.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
The Coordination Challenge
Can competing firms coordinate pricing without explicit contracts?
Obstacles:

Individual profit motives conflict with group interest (monopoly profit)
No legal mechanism to enforce agreements
Constant temptation to cheat on “deals”

Result: The non-cooperative (Nash) equilibrium is Pareto-dominated by coordinated outcomes.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Facilitating Devices
Firms use facilitating devices to overcome coordination problems:

Increase incentives to cooperate — benefit from higher prices
Decrease incentives to cheat — punishment for deviation

Legal examples:

Most-Favoured-Nation (MFN) clauses
Most-Favoured-Customer (MFC) clauses







Policy Scrutiny


These devices alter payoff structures in ways that enable tacit collusion; competition authorities scrutinise them accordingly.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
The Prisoner’s Dilemma: Setup
Two firms, one period. Payoff matrix:




High Price
Low Price




High Price
100, 100
-10, 140


Low Price
140, -10
70, 70



Nash equilibrium: \((p_L, p_L)\) with payoffs \(70,\, 70\)
Cooperative outcome: \((p_H, p_H)\) with payoffs \(100,\, 100\)
Problem: Cooperation is not a Nash equilibrium without commitment or repeated-game structure.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Why Coordination Fails: Incentive Incompatibility
Starting from \((p_L, p_L)\), why cannot both firms coordinate on \((p_H, p_H)\)?
Sequential move problem:

First-mover disadvantage: Leader gets payoff \(-10\) while follower earns \(140\)
Incentive to delay: Follower waits to capture the \(140\)
Leader’s temptation to revert: Seeing no response, leader drops back to \(p_L\)







Coordination Failure


Unilateral deviation is profitable from any proposed high-price agreement; hence the prisoner’s dilemma equilibrium is the unique Nash equilibrium of the simultaneous-move game.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
section: Solving Coordination: The Adjusted Payoff Matrix
text:
Solving Coordination: The Adjusted Payoff Matrix
Reduce follower’s transitional gain:




High Price

100, 100
-10, 90


Low Price
90, -10
70, 70



Then \((p_H, p_H)\) is a Nash equilibrium in the single-period game.
Equilibrium characterisation:

If firm moves to \(p_H\), it earns \(-10\) in the transition
Given the opponent is at \(p_H\), best response is also \(p_H\), earning \(100\)
Both firms converge to \((p_H, p_H)\) with payoffs 100, 100 (symmetric equilibrium)

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Most-Favoured-Nation (MFN) Clause Explained
What is an MFN clause?
A seller commits to:

Charge a specified minimum price
Refund buyers if a lower price is offered later
Pay penalties equivalent to price differences

Effect:








Action
Without MFN
With MFN




Price cut benefit
Capture all new buyers
Lose many to refunds


Price cut cost
Minimal
Refund obligations + penalties



\(\rightarrow\) MFN raises the cost of deviation from high price.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
MFN as Self-Enforcement
For MFN to work, it must be self-enforcing:
\[
\text{Gross profit from deviation} - \text{Refunds} < \text{Profit under MFN}
\]
Example:

Gross profit gain from cutting price: \(0.897\)
Refunds owed to existing customers: \(0.056\)
Net gain: \(0.841\) (which is less than staying at MFN price)

\(\rightarrow\) Deviation becomes unprofitable.






Free Rider Effect in Reverse (Salop 1985)


Individual buyers value MFN protection, but collectively it harms them by preventing sellers from offering discounts to future customers.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Numerical Example: Setup
Bertrand duopoly with differentiated products:
Demand:
\[Q_1 = 3 - 2p_1 + p_2\] \[Q_2 = 3 + p_1 - 2p_2\]
Costs: \(c_1 = c_2 = 1\)

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Baseline Bertrand Equilibrium
Best response functions:
\[
BR_i(p_j) = \frac{5 + p_j}{4}
\]
Equilibrium:

\(p_1^B = p_2^B = \frac{5}{3} \approx 1.667\)
\(\pi_i^B = \frac{8}{9} \approx 0.889\)

Question: Can Firm 1 increase profits by adopting an MFN clause?

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Firm 1 Adopts MFN Clause
Firm 1 commits to price \(p_1^* = \frac{12}{7} \approx 1.714\)
Firm 2’s best response:
\[
p_2^* = BR_2(p_1^*) = \frac{47}{28} \approx 1.678
\]
Outcomes:

\(Q_1^* = \frac{5}{4}\)
\(\pi_1^* = \frac{25}{28} \approx 0.893 > 0.889\)







Note


Firm 1’s profits rise to \(\approx 0.893\) from the Bertrand equilibrium level of \(0.889\) by committing to a higher price via the MFN clause.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Can Firm 1 Deviate from MFN?
Firm 1 considers deviating to \(\tilde{p}_1 = BR_1(p_2^*) = \frac{187}{112} \approx 1.669\)
Gross profit from deviation:

\(\tilde{Q}_1 = \frac{75}{56}\)
\(\tilde{\pi}_1 = \frac{5625}{6272} \approx 0.897\)

But MFN requires refunds:
\[
\text{Refunds} = Q_1^* (p_1^* - \tilde{p}_1) = \frac{25}{448} \approx 0.056
\]
Net profit after refunds:
\[
\tilde{\pi}_1 - \text{Refunds} = \frac{5275}{6272} \approx 0.841
\]






Important


Net profit from deviation (\(0.841\)) is strictly less than profit under MFN commitment (\(0.893\)). The MFN clause is thus self-enforcing: no firm has incentive to deviate unilaterally.

title: Lecture 1 - Oligopoly
text:
Summary: Oligopoly Coordination
Key takeaways:

Coordination problem: Joint profit maximisation yields higher payoffs than Nash equilibrium, but the cooperative outcome is not self-enforcing in simultaneous-move games
Single-period dilemma: The Nash equilibrium is Pareto-inefficient
Facilitating devices: MFN clauses alter the payoff structure to align individual and collective incentives

text: Instructions

title: Exercise 1: Oligopoly and Product Differentiation
text:
Problem 1: Welfare analysis
Consider the example exercise in Lecture 1, where
\(P = 20 - Q\)
and there are three firms with cost function \(c_i(q_i) = c_i q_i\) with
\(c_1 = 0\), \(c_2 = 5\), and \(c_3 = 7\).

(a)
Compute the Nash equilibrium of the Cournot duopoly game between firm 1 and firm 2.


(b)
Given your answer to (a), compute the equilibrium profits, consumer surplus, and welfare loss.


(c)
Compare the values in (b) to those of the other three market structures (perfect competition, monopoly, Cournot triopoly) in Lecture 1. Discuss any policy implications for a social planner who maximises total welfare.
{{< if params.solution >}}

title: Exercise 1: Oligopoly and Product Differentiation
text:
Solution

(a)
The best response functions are
\[
q_1 = \frac{20 - q_2}{2}
\qquad \text{and} \qquad
q_2 = \frac{15 - q_1}{2}.
\]
Solving this system yields the equilibrium quantities
\[
q_1^D = \frac{25}{3},
\qquad
q_2^D = \frac{10}{3}.
\]


(b)
The equilibrium price is
\[
P(Q^D) = 20 - \frac{35}{3} = \frac{25}{3}.
\]
Consumer surplus is therefore
\[
CS^D = \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{35}{3}\right)^2 = \frac{1225}{18},
\]
and producer surplus is
\[
PS^D = \Pi_1 + \Pi_2
= \left(\frac{25}{3}\right)^2 + \left(\frac{10}{3}\right)^2
= \frac{725}{9}.
\]
The welfare loss is
\[
WL^D = 200 - \frac{1225}{18} - \frac{725}{9}
= \frac{925}{18}.
\]


(c)
The values for all three welfare components fall between those of monopoly and Cournot triopoly:
\[
CS^M < CS^D < CS^T,
\qquad
PS^M > PS^D > PS^T,
\qquad
WL^M < WL^D < WL^T.
\]
As the number of producing firms increases (monopoly \(\to\) Cournot duopoly \(\to\) Cournot triopoly), prices fall and consumer surplus increases, but production is reallocated toward higher-cost firms (reducing productive efficiency).
{{< endif >}}

section: Problem 2: Linear Hotelling model with monopoly
text:
Problem 2: Linear Hotelling model with monopoly
Consider the Hotelling linear-city model. Suppose there is only one restaurant, located at the centre of a street of length 1 km. The restaurant’s cost is zero.
Consumers are uniformly distributed on the interval \([0,1]\), with one consumer at each point. Transportation cost is £1 per kilometre.
The utility of a consumer located at distance \(a\) from the restaurant is
\[
U = B - a - p,
\]
where \(p\) is the price of a meal and \(B\) is a constant.
If the consumer does not eat at the restaurant, utility is
\[
U^* = 0.
\]

(a)
Suppose \(0 < B < 1\). Find the number of consumers eating at the restaurant. Calculate the monopoly price and profit.


(b)
Answer the previous question assuming \(B > 1\).
{{< if params.solution >}}

title: Exercise 1: Oligopoly and Product Differentiation
text:
Solution

(a)
Let \(d_m\) denote the distance of the marginal consumer from the restaurant. Indifference implies
\[
B - d_m - p = 0
\quad \Rightarrow \quad
d_m = B - p.
\]
Demand is
\[
q = 2 d_m = 2(B - p).
\]
The monopolist solves
\[
\max_p \ \Pi(p) = p \cdot 2(B - p).
\]
FOC implies \(p^M=\frac{B}{2}\), hence \(q^M=B\) and \(\Pi^M=\frac{B^2}{2}\).


(b)
For \(B>1\), the unconstrained solution implies \(d_m=\frac{B}{2}>\frac{1}{2}\), but demand cannot exceed 1, so \(q=1\).
The monopolist sets price so the marginal consumers are exactly at the endpoints (\(d=\frac{1}{2}\)):
\[
B - \frac{1}{2} - p = 0
\quad \Rightarrow \quad
p^* = B - \frac{1}{2}.
\]
Then \(\Pi^*=p^*\cdot 1 = B - \frac{1}{2}\).

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Differentiation types

Horizontal: consumers disagree on which variety is best (ideal-point / mismatch preferences)
Vertical: products differ in quality; at equal prices all consumers (weakly) prefer the higher-quality good

Today: roadmap

Focus: horizontal differentiation
Hotelling line: 2 firms, pricing with fixed locations
Salop circular city: free entry and welfare

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Setup: Fixed locations, price competition

Duopoly, marginal cost \(0\)
Consumers (\(\ell\)) uniformly distributed on \([0,L]\) (Hotelling (1929) line)
Firm 1 at \(a\) and Firm 2 at \(L-b\)
Mismatch (transport) cost \(C(d)=cd\) with \(c>0\), \(d\) extent of mismatch
Unit demand; assume full market coverage in equilibrium








Utility (full coverage)


\(U_1(\ell)=\bar u - p_1 - c|\ell-a|\), \(U_2(\ell)=\bar u - p_2 - c|\ell-(L-b)|\), outside option \(0\); assume \(\bar u\) is large enough that all consumers buy.

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Geometry


Choice variables: \(p_1, p_2\)
Parameters: \(L, a, b, c\)
Distance between firms: \(L-a-b\)
Marginal consumer distances: \(x+y=L-a-b\)
Demands: \(q_1=a+x\) and \(q_2=b+y\)

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Marginal consumer and demands

Indifference of the marginal consumer: \(p_1 + cx = p_2 + cy\)
Geometry: \(x+y=L-a-b\)

Demands by firm

\(q_1 = a + x = \frac{p_2 - p_1 + c(L + a - b)}{2c}\)
\(q_2 = b + y = \frac{p_1 - p_2 + c(L + b - a)}{2c}\)

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Best responses

\(BR_1(p_2)=\frac{p_2}{2}+\frac{c}{2}(L+a-b)\)
\(BR_2(p_1)=\frac{p_1}{2}+\frac{c}{2}(L+b-a)\)







Warning


Prices are strategic complements; if \(a=b\) then \(p_1^*=p_2^*\)

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Price equilibrium fixed locations

Prices: \(p_1^* = c\left(L + \frac{a-b}{3}\right)\) and \(p_2^* = c\left(L + \frac{b-a}{3}\right)\)
Profits: \(\pi_1^* = \frac{c}{18}(3L + a - b)^2\) and \(\pi_2^* = \frac{c}{18}(3L + b - a)^2\)
If \(a=b\), symmetry implies \(p_1^*=p_2^*\)
Higher \(c\) lowers substitutability and raises equilibrium markups and profits

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Hotelling: co-location

Co-location implies \(a+b=L\) and \(x=y=0\)
Products become homogeneous \(\Rightarrow\) Bertrand undercutting
Equilibrium: \(p_1^B=p_2^B=0\) and \(\pi_1^B=\pi_2^B=0\)







Warning


Co-location and price competition
Co-location removes captive consumers; any \(p>0\) can be profitably undercut.

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Move incentives at fixed prices

\(\frac{\partial \pi_1^*}{\partial a} = \frac{c}{9}(3L + a - b) > 0\) and \(\frac{\partial \pi_2^*}{\partial b} = \frac{c}{9}(3L + b - a) > 0\)
In the pricing subgame, increasing \(a\) (resp. \(b\)) moves Firm 1 (resp. Firm 2) inward (toward the centre)
These are comparative statics holding the rival location fixed
Under linear transport costs, pricing incentives can pull locations toward the centre firms will “go where the demand is”

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Identifying clustering motives
Question Why are so many businesses clustered together?

Going where the demand is?
Possible collusion story? Being next to the competitor facilitates monitoring?

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Location game (d’Aspremont et al., 1979)

Two-stage game: choose locations, then prices
Linear transport costs (\(C(d)=cd\)): pure-strategy location equilibrium may fail to exist (market-capture regions; non-concavity)
Quadratic transport costs (\(C(d)=td^2\)): pure-strategy location equilibrium exists (baseline: maximum differentiation)
Principle of minimum differentiation need not hold







Note


Why convexity matters
More convex mismatch costs make small location changes less effective at stealing marginal consumers through pricing.

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Profit function

Let \(\Delta \equiv L-a-b\) denote the distance between firms
In the price subgame (locations fixed), Firm 1’s profit is piecewise in \((p_1,p_2)\) (d’Aspremont et al., 1979)

\[\pi_1(p_1, p_2) =
\begin{cases}
\frac{p_1 p_2}{2c} - \frac{p_1^2}{2c} + \frac{(L+a-b)p_1}{2}
& \text{if } |p_1 - p_2| \le c(L - a - b) \\[0.5em]
Lp_1 & \text{if } p_1 < p_2 - c(L - a - b) \\[0.5em]
0 & \text{if } p_1 > p_2 + c(L - a - b)
\end{cases}\]

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Profit regions

Region 1 (interior): both firms serve positive mass of consumers; demand is linear in \(p_1\)
Region 2 (market capture): Firm 1 undercuts enough to serve the whole line segment
Region 3 (no demand): Firm 1 sets too high a price; demand is zero

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Setup

Outside good yields utility \(u^*\)
Differentiated varieties lie on a circle of circumference 1; consumers are uniformly distributed (Salop, 1979)
\(n\) firms are symmetrically located; adjacent distance is \(\frac{1}{n}\)
Each consumer buys at most one unit: from some firm or the outside good

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Objects

Choice variable: \(p_i\)
Parameters: \(n, c, u, u^*\)
Outcomes: market boundaries / cutoffs, quantities

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Consumers

Each consumer has an ideal variety \(\ell^*\) (location on the circle)
Arc distance \(d\) generates mismatch cost \(cd\)
Utility from firm \(j\): \(U_j = u - cd_j - p_j\)
Outside option: \(U^O=u^*\)
Let \(v=u-u^*\); participation requires \(v \ge p_j + cd_j\)

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Monopoly region

Outside option truncates the market (participation binds), not neighbours
Farthest served consumer: \(d_m=\frac{v-p}{c}\)
Monopoly demand: \(q^M = 2d_m = 2\left(\frac{v-p}{c}\right)\)

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Monopoly inverse demand

Inverse demand: \(p = v - \frac{c}{2} q^M\)
Slope is \(-\frac{c}{2}\) because expanding quantity extends the served interval on both sides
Participation binds at the marginal consumer: \(v = p + cd_m\)

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Competitive region

Boundary consumer (indifference): \(v - cx - p = v - c\left(\frac{1}{n} - x\right) - \tilde{p}\)
Boundary location: \(x = \frac{\frac{c}{n} - p + \tilde{p}}{2c}\)
Competitive quantity: \(q^C = 2x\)

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Competitive demand

Competitive demand: \(q^C = 2x = \frac{\frac{c}{n} - p + \tilde{p}}{c}\)
Inverse demand: \(p = \frac{c}{n} + \tilde{p} - c q^C\)







Important


Slope comparison
Competitive-region inverse demand is steeper than monopoly-region inverse demand: \(-c\) vs \(-\frac{c}{2}\).

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Kinked demand

Demand is limited either by the outside option (participation) or by neighbours (local competition)
Effective demand is \(q(p)=\min\{q^M(p),q^C(p)\}\)

Participation-boundary (monopoly region): \(q^M = 2\left(\frac{v-p}{c}\right)\)
Neighbour-boundary (competitive region): \(q^C = \frac{\frac{c}{n} - p + \tilde{p}}{c}\)

The switch in the binding constraint creates a kink in inverse demand and a discrete change in marginal revenue

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Cost functions

Cost function: \(C(q)=F + mq\) (fixed cost \(F\), marginal cost \(m\))
Average cost: \(AC(q)=m+\frac{F}{q}\) (decreasing in \(q\))

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Pricing (competitive region)

Inverse demand: \(p = \frac{c}{n} + \tilde{p} - cq\)
Marginal revenue: \(MR = \frac{c}{n} + \tilde{p} - 2cq\)
Symmetry: \(\tilde{p}=p\)








Competitive-region condition (outside option not binding)


In a symmetric profile, the farthest consumer from a firm is at distance \(\frac{1}{2n}\). A sufficient condition for the competitive region to apply at the symmetric equilibrium is \(v \ge p^C + \frac{c}{2n}\).

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Zero profit

Symmetry implies \(q^C=\frac{1}{n}\)
Zero profit requires \(p^C = AC = m + \frac{F}{q^C}\)
Therefore \(p^C = m + nF\)

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Pricing condition

Competitive-region inverse demand: \(p = \frac{c}{n} + \tilde{p} - cq\)
First-order condition: \(MR=MC\) with \(MR = \frac{c}{n} + \tilde{p} - 2cq\) and \(MC=m\)
Symmetric equilibrium implication: with \(\tilde{p}=p\) and \(q^C=\frac{1}{n}\), we get \(p^C = m + \frac{c}{n}\)

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Free-entry equilibrium

Zero profit condition: \(p^C = m + nF\)
Solve: \(m+nF = m+\frac{c}{n}\) so \(n^C = \sqrt{\frac{c}{F}}\) and \(p^C = m + \sqrt{cF}\)
Comparative statics: \(n^C\) increases in \(c\) and decreases in \(F\)

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Welfare

Average distance to the nearest firm: \(\bar d = \frac{1}{4n}\)
Resource cost of variety: \(nF\)
With quasilinear utility, prices are transfers
Per-consumer welfare: \(W(n) = v - \frac{c}{4n} - nF\) (where \(v=u-u^*\))

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Social planner solution
Planner problem: Choose \(n\) to maximise \(W(n)\)

FOC: \(\frac{dW}{dn}=\frac{c}{4n^2}-F=0\)
Social optimum: \(n^S=\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{\frac{c}{F}}\)
Free entry: \(n^C=\sqrt{\frac{c}{F}}\) so \(n^C=2n^S\)

Excess entry due to business stealing externality

title: Lecture 2 – Product Differentiation
text:
Summary and next week

Mismatch costs soften price competition (markups increase in \(c\))
Hotelling: demand, best responses, and equilibrium prices with fixed locations
Salop: free entry gives \(n^C=\sqrt{\frac{c}{F}}\) and implies excess entry relative to the planner

Next week:

Innovation under uncertainty
Oligopoly incentives to innovate (replacement effect, entry threat)

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
IPRs: economic problem






Object of analysis


IPRs make a non-rival good partially excludable, creating private incentives for costly innovation.




Knowledge is (partly) non-rival and often hard to exclude
Without protection, imitation can dissipate rents \(\Rightarrow\) weak private incentive to incur fixed R&D cost
Policy objective

Provide incentives for invention while limiting static distortions in product markets

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
IPRs: instruments

Main IPR types:

Patents
Trademarks
Copyrights
Design rights

Key design dimensions (patents):

Length (duration)
Breadth (scope)
Geographical coverage
Transferability (sale, licensing)

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
IPRs: central trade-off

Patents create temporary market power \(\Rightarrow\) static deadweight loss
Stronger protection (longer/broader) typically:

increases expected private returns to R&D
increases the static distortion during protection

Questions:

What is an optimal length and breadth?
How does competition in R&D (patent races) affect efficiency?

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Ideas model (Scotchmer): primitives
Following Scotchmer (2006)

An “idea” is a pair \((\nu, F)\)
\(\nu\): per-period consumer surplus under competitive supply (value parameter)
\(F\): fixed cost to develop the idea into an innovation (R&D cost)
Interpretation

\(\nu\) captures the size of social gains from making the idea usable
\(F\) is the up-front resource cost required for development

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
section: Ideas model (Scotchmer): social value under discounting
text:
Ideas model (Scotchmer): social value under discounting
Assume social value lasts forever and the product is competitively supplied.

Per-period social value: \(\nu\)
Discounted social value:

\[
\sum_{t=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(1+r)^t}\nu = \frac{\nu}{r}
\]

Interpretation

Discount rate \(r\) reduces the present value of long-run benefits
Longer-lived benefits (lower \(r\)) raise the social value of an idea

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
section: Ideas model (Scotchmer): private returns and deadweight loss
text:
Ideas model (Scotchmer): private returns and deadweight loss

Firm’s per-period private profit under patent: \(\pi \nu\) where \(0<\pi<1\)
Patent profit for discounted length \(T\):

\[
\pi \nu T
\]

Per-period deadweight loss: \(\ell \nu\) \(\Rightarrow\) patent DWL: \(\ell \nu T\)
Interpretation

\(\pi\) is a reduced-form “appropriability” parameter
\(\ell\) captures the static distortion created by protection

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Discounted patent length: \(T\)

Let \(\tau\) be the undiscounted duration (in periods)
Define discounted duration:

\[
T = \int_0^{\tau} e^{-rt} \, dt = \frac{1-e^{-r\tau}}{r}
\]

Discrete-time approximation used in many models:

\[
T \approx \sum_{t=1}^{\tau}\frac{1}{(1+r)^t}
\]

Interpretation

\(T\) is increasing in \(\tau\) but bounded as \(\tau\to\infty\) when \(r>0\)

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Optimal patent length: innovating firm

Patent gives discounted net profit:

\[
\pi \nu T - F
\]

Firm invests if \(\pi \nu T \ge F\)
Interpretation

Higher \(\nu\) or larger \(\pi\) reduces the minimum protection needed for investment
Higher \(F\) requires longer (or stronger) protection to break even

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Optimal patent length: social planner

Discounted net social value (invention made):

\[
\frac{\nu}{r} - \ell \nu T
\]

Interpretation

Planner values the full flow benefit \(\nu\), but counts DWL during protection
Optimal design trades off inducing investment against static costs

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Optimal length: heterogeneity and screening (intuition)

If inventions differ in \((\nu,F)\), “one-size-fits-all” length is not generally optimal
Comparative statics (holding other parameters fixed):

more elastic demand / stronger substitution \(\Rightarrow\) higher DWL \(\ell\) \(\Rightarrow\) shorter protection
higher development cost \(F\) \(\Rightarrow\) longer protection to ensure investment

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Example: ideas A and B

Idea A: \((\nu_A=5, F_A=10)\)
Idea B: \((\nu_B=2, F_B=20)\)

Let \(T=20\), \(\pi=\tfrac{1}{2}\), \(\ell=\tfrac{1}{4}\), \(r=\tfrac{1}{3}\).

Tasks:

Which ideas are privately profitable (\(\pi \nu T \ge F\))?
Which ideas have positive discounted net social value \(\left(\frac{\nu}{r}-\ell \nu T - F \ge 0\right)\)?

Interpretation

With these parameter values, private profitability need not coincide with positive net social value: patent protection can induce investment even when net welfare is negative

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Patent breadth: product space (definition)

Breadth determines how close a substitute can be without infringing
Reduced-form implication:

Narrower breadth \(\Rightarrow\) more close substitutes enter
Broader breadth \(\Rightarrow\) fewer close substitutes enter

Interpretation

Allowing close substitutes increases the elasticity of demand faced by the patent holder

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Breadth and demand elasticity (intuition)

If close substitutes are allowed:

residual demand becomes more elastic
equilibrium price is lower (all else equal)

If substitutes are excluded (broader patent):

residual demand is less elastic
equilibrium price is higher (all else equal)

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Breadth–length trade-off (given a target value)
Assume the “correct” expected private value of protection is fixed.






Regimes (product space)



Broad–short: \((\hat{T}, \hat{\pi}_1+\hat{\pi}_2)\)
Narrow–long: \((\tilde{T}, \tilde{\pi}_1)\)





Broad patent yields higher per-period profit (includes infringing market):

\[
\hat{T}(\hat{\pi}_1+\hat{\pi}_2)=\tilde{T}\tilde{\pi}_1
\]

Therefore:

\[
\hat{T}<\tilde{T}
\]

Interpretation

Broad protection can be paired with shorter duration to deliver the same incentive level

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Which regime is better?

The best regime depends on substitution patterns:

substitution between the patented good and an infringing substitute
substitution between these goods and the rest of consumption

Interpretation

Broad–short: more sensitive to outside substitution (pricing alignment across many goods)
Narrow–long: more sensitive to within-category substitution

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Shy (1995) model: setup

Demand: \(P(Q)=a-Q\)
Process innovation reduces marginal cost from \(c\) to \(c-x\)
R&D effort \(x\) costs \(R(x)\)
Two-stage game:

Regulator chooses patent duration \(\tau\)
Firm chooses \(x\) to maximise discounted profit

Objects

Choice variables: \(x\) (firm), \(\tau\) (regulator)
Parameters: \(a,c,r\)

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
section: Shy model: firm’s choice of \(x\) given \(\tau\)
text:
Shy model: firm’s choice of \(x\) given \(\tau\)
Firm solves:
\[
\max_x \ \Pi(x;\tau)=\sum_{t=1}^{\tau}\rho^{t-1}\pi(x)-R(x),
\quad \rho=\frac{1}{1+r}
\]
Assume:

per-period profit: \(\pi(x)=(a-c)\,x\)
cost: \(R(x)=\frac{x^2}{2}\)
Lemma:

\[
\sum_{t=1}^{\tau}\rho^{t-1}=\frac{1-\rho^\tau}{1-\rho}
\]

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Shy model: induced innovation level
FOC implies:
\[
x^I(\tau)=\frac{1-\rho^\tau}{1-\rho}(a-c)
\]

Comparative statics:

\(x^I\) increases with \(\tau\)
\(x^I\) increases with \(a\) and decreases with \(c\)
\(x^I\) increases with \(\rho\) (decreases with \(r\))

Interpretation

Longer protection raises the marginal benefit of R&D because profits are earned for more discounted periods

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
section: Shy model: planner’s choice of patent duration (statement)
text:
Shy model: planner’s choice of patent duration (statement)
Planner chooses \(\tau\) trading off: - higher induced innovation \(x^I(\tau)\) - static deadweight loss under monopoly pricing during protection

Result (as in Shy): optimal duration is finite, \(T^*<\infty\)
Interpretation

Marginal benefit of longer protection (higher induced \(x^I(\tau)\)) eventually falls below the marginal cost (additional monopoly distortion during protection)

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Symmetric patent race: setup

Two symmetric firms may incur a fixed cost \(f\) to establish a research division
Success probability: \(p\) (per firm)
Payoffs:

monopoly profit if sole innovator: \(\pi^m\)
duopoly profit if both succeed: \(\pi^d\)

Welfare benchmarks (post-innovation welfare):

one research division: \(W^m=\pi^m+CS^m\)
two research divisions: \(W^d=2\pi^d+CS^d\)

Assumption (for the comparison):

\(CS^d>CS^m\) (more competition in the product market raises consumer surplus)

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Patent race: Nash equilibrium condition






Duplication incentive


“Winner-takes-all” payoffs can create privately excessive entry into R&D when firms ignore duplication costs.




Firms choose \(I\) or \(NI\) simultaneously
\((I,I)\) is a Nash equilibrium if:

\[
f \le p(1-p)\pi^m + p^2\pi^d \equiv f^{priv}_2
\]

Interpretation

Private incentives include the probability of being the unique winner and the case where both succeed

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Patent race: social optimum condition

It is socially optimal to have one research division rather than two if:

\[
f \ge p(1-2p)W^m + p^2W^d \equiv f^{publ}_2
\]

Interpretation

The planner compares expected welfare under one vs two research divisions, counting duplication cost \(f\)

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
Socially excessive R&D (region)

Socially excessive duplication occurs when:

\[
f^{publ}_2 < f < f^{priv}_2
\]

Interpretation:

Firms overinvest when the negative externality on rivals’ profits outweighs the consumer-surplus gain from having two innovators

title: Lecture 4 - Patents and Intellectual Property Rights
text:
References




• Scotchmer, Suzanne (2006). Innovation and incentives. MIT Press, Cambridge, MA, USA.


• Shy, Oz (1995). Industrial organization: Theory and applications. MIT Press, Cambridge, Mass.

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
text:
Cooperative R&D: overview






Object of analysis


R&D cooperation when R&D creates spillovers (\(\beta>0\)) or allows cost sharing (RJV).




Baseline: each firm chooses R&D privately and internalises only its own costs/benefits
This lecture:

R&D spillovers and the incentive to coordinate R&D
Research joint ventures (RJVs) as cost-sharing arrangements

Core question:

When does cooperation increase welfare relative to non-cooperative R&D?

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
text:
Multi-stage games: reminder

Two-stage structure:

Stage 1: choose \(x_i\) (R&D)
Stage 2: choose \(q_i\) (product-market competition)








Backward induction


Solve Stage 2 for \(q_i^*(x)\), substitute into Stage 1 payoffs, then solve for \(x^*\).

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
text:
Spillovers model: primitives

Duopoly with inverse demand:

\[
p(Q) = A - Q,\quad Q=q_1+q_2
\]

Cost and spillovers:

Marginal cost of firm \(i\): \(c_i = c - x_i - \beta x_j\) with \(\beta\in(0,1)\)
Feasibility: \(x_i + \beta x_j \le c\)

R&D cost:

Firm \(i\) pays \(\frac{x_i^2}{2}\)

Objects:

Choice variables: \(x_i\) (stage 1), \(q_i\) (stage 2)
Parameters: \(A, c, \beta\)








Spillover parameter


\(\beta\in(0,1)\) measures how much of firm \(j\)’s R&D reduces firm \(i\)’s marginal cost.

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
text:
Spillovers model: stage-2 profit

Given \((x_1,x_2)\), firm \(i\) chooses \(q_i\) to maximise:

\[
\pi_i(q_i;q_j,x_i,x_j)=[A-(q_i+q_j)-c_i]q_i-\frac{x_i^2}{2}
\]

Interpretation:

R&D shifts marginal cost; output competition determines how much cost reduction is monetised

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
text:
Product-market equilibrium (Cournot): quantities

Cournot–Nash equilibrium quantities (given \(x_1,x_2\)):

\[
q_i^*=\frac{1}{3}\Big[(A-c)+(2-\beta)x_i+(2\beta-1)x_j\Big]
\]

Interpretation:

Own R&D raises own output; rival R&D can raise or lower own output depending on spillover strength








Strategic effect of spillovers


The term \((2\beta-1)x_j\) implies rival R&D can be output-increasing or output-reducing depending on whether \(\beta\) is above or below \(\tfrac{1}{2}\).

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
text:
Regimes: definition

We compare three institutional regimes:
Game I:

Non-cooperative R&D and non-cooperative output (Cournot)

Game II:

Cooperative R&D, non-cooperative output (Cournot)

Game III:

Cooperative R&D and cooperative output (joint profit maximisation)

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
text:
Game I: stage-1 problem (non-cooperative R&D)

Stage 1 objective for firm \(i\):

\[
\max_{x_i}\ \pi_i^*(x_i,x_j)=[q_i^*(x_i,x_j)]^2-\frac{x_i^2}{2}
\]

Symmetric equilibrium (\(x_1=x_2=x^*\)):

\[
x^*=\frac{(A-c)(2-\beta)}{4.5-(2-\beta)(1+\beta)}
\]

Interpretation:

Each firm invests less when spillovers are high because part of the benefit accrues to the rival

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
text:
Game II: stage-1 problem (cooperative R&D)

Firms choose \((x_1,x_2)\) to maximise joint profit given Cournot output:

\[
\max_{x_1,x_2}\ \hat{\pi}=\pi_1^*+\pi_2^*
\]

Symmetric solution (\(x_1=x_2=\hat{x}\)):

\[
\hat{x}=\frac{(A-c)(1+\beta)}{4.5-(1+\beta)^2}
\]

Interpretation:

Internalising spillovers increases R&D relative to Game I (for intermediate \(\beta\))

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
section: Game III: cooperative R&D and output
text:
Game III: cooperative R&D and output

With full cooperation, firms maximise joint profit over \((q_1,q_2,x_1,x_2)\)
Under symmetry (\(x_1=x_2=x\), \(q_1=q_2\)), aggregate output in stage 2 is:

\[
\tilde{Q}=\frac{(A-c)+(1+\beta)x}{2}
\]

Stage 1 chooses \(x\) to maximise joint profit; solution:

\[
\tilde{x}=\frac{(A-c)(1+\beta)}{4-(1+\beta)^2}
\]

Interpretation:

Output coordination reduces product-market competition; R&D incentives differ because they are evaluated at monopoly output

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
text:
Welfare benchmark: social planner
Assume symmetry \(x_1=x_2=x\).

Welfare function (as stated in the lecture):

\[
W(Q)=V(Q)+R(Q)-[c-(1+\beta)x]Q-x^2
\]

Stage 2 FOC w.r.t. \(Q\):

\[
Q=A-c+(1+\beta)x
\]

Interpretation:

Planner expands output to the efficient level given the cost reduction from total effective R&D

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
text:
Social optimum: R&D and output

Socially optimal R&D:

\[
x^{**}=\frac{(A-c)(1+\beta)}{2-(1+\beta)^2}
\]

Socially optimal output:

\[
Q^{**}=(A-c)\left[\frac{2}{2-(1+\beta)^2}\right]
\]

Interpretation:

Relative to market outcomes, the planner internalises both spillovers and the consumer-surplus gain from lower prices

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
section: Comparing regimes: R&D and output rankings
text:
Comparing regimes: R&D and output rankings

R&D expenditure comparison (from the lecture):

Large spillovers: \(x^{**}>\tilde{x}>\hat{x}>x^*\)
Small spillovers: \(x^{**}>\tilde{x}\ge x^*>\hat{x}\)

Output comparison (from the lecture):

Large spillovers: \(Q^{**}>\hat{Q}>Q^*>\tilde{Q}\)
Small spillovers: \(Q^{**}>Q^*>\hat{Q}>\tilde{Q}\)








Reading the rankings


Higher \(x\) need not imply higher \(Q\) when cooperation also changes the intensity of product-market competition.

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
text:
RJV model: primitives

Probability a single lab succeeds: \(p\)
Product-market profits:

Monopoly: \(\pi^m\)
Duopoly: \(\pi^d\)

Fixed cost of a lab: \(F\)
Assumptions:

If both succeed, firms compete in the product market (profits \(\pi^d\) each)
If only one succeeds (non-cooperative setting), the innovator earns \(\pi^m\)

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
text:
RJV: cost-sharing (single lab)

Each cooperating firm’s expected payoff:

\[
V_C=p\pi^d-\frac{F}{2}
\]

Non-cooperating firm’s expected payoff:

\[
V_N=p(1-p)\pi^m+p^2\pi^d-F
\]

Cooperation condition:

\[
V_C\ge V_N \quad\Leftrightarrow\quad \frac{F}{2}\ge p(1-p)(\pi^m-\pi^d)
\]

Interpretation:

Cooperation is more attractive when the “winner-takes-all” component \(p(1-p)\) is small

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
text:
RJV: duplication (two labs)

If the RJV runs two labs (duplication), payoff of each cooperating firm:

\[
\tilde{V}_C=2p\pi^d-F
\]

Non-cooperating payoff remains \(V_N\)
Cooperation condition:

\[
\tilde{V}_C\ge \tilde{V}_N \quad\Leftrightarrow\quad p\ge \frac{\pi^m-2\pi^d}{\pi^m-\pi^d}\equiv K
\]

Interpretation:

With duplication, cooperation depends mainly on success probability \(p\) (not on \(F\))

title: Lecture 6 – Cooperative R&D
text:
Summary & references
Summary

Spillovers \(\beta>0\) create an externality in R&D, so non-cooperative R&D can be inefficiently low
Cooperative R&D internalises spillovers and can increase R&D relative to non-cooperative choices
Full cooperation may reduce product-market competition, affecting output and welfare
RJVs trade off cost sharing against strategic effects from duplication and winning probabilities

References
